sourceDesc.p: Created by members of the TLS project
Comments and notes to 南華真經註疏for translation .

{NB: "should" is another interpolation that shifts the meaning. Guo is *stating* that it is metaphorical. The reader needs to be careful here, it seems to me. One might assume Guo is finally recognizing the work as fiction, but that would be a mistaken assumption: the story of 藐姑射 and 神人 could very well be factual for Guo (as later annotations indicate). Instead, his point is that ZZ conveys a message indirectly through this possibly factual story.}

Ziporyn 2009: When the physical form alters,
Ziporyn 2009: the dispositions change with it.
Ziporyn 2009: Formerly, being a fish,
Ziporyn 2009: he swam the depths of the Northern Ocean.
Ziporyn 2009: Now that he has become a bird,
Ziporyn 2009: he soars over the Southern Sea.
Ziporyn 2009: Although being submerged and being aloft may differ in nature,
Ziporyn 2009: he is equally far-reaching and unfettered in both. {NB: Ziporyn uses a singular pronoun.}
Ziporyn 2009: Whatever thousands of changes and ten thousands of transformations I may go through,
Ziporyn 2009: “Heaven and earth”
Ziporyn 2009: is just a blanket term used to indicate allbeings.
Ziporyn 2009: It is all individual beings that form the very substance of heaven and earth,
Ziporyn 2009: and it is each being’s self-so that aligns true to itself.
Ziporyn 2009: “Self-so”
Ziporyn 2009: means what is so of itself, without being done by anyone or for any purpose.
Ziporyn 2009: Thus, Peng’s ability to fly high
Ziporyn 2009: and the sparrow’s ability to stay low,
Ziporyn 2009: the great tree’s ability to last long
Ziporyn 2009: and the mushroom’s ability to perish quickly,
Ziporyn 2009: all these are done spontaneously, all are self-so;
Ziporyn 2009: they are beyond the ability of anyone’s particular activity.
Ziporyn 2009: Because these are self-so capabilities not done by anyone or for any purpose,
Ziporyn 2009: they are aligned true [to themselves].
Ziporyn 2009: Thus, to “chariot upon what is true both to Heaven and to earth”
Ziporyn 2009: means to follow along with the character of each thing.
Ziporyn 2009: To ride “atop the back-and-forth of the six atmospheric breaths”
Ziporyn 2009: means to wander in the paths of transformation and change.
Ziporyn 2009: If you travel forth like this,
Ziporyn 2009: where can you go that will bring you to a halt?
Ziporyn 2009: If you can ride upon whatever you happen to encounter,
Ziporyn 2009: what will you have to depend on?
Ziporyn 2009: This is how the perfect Virtuoso, who vanishingly unifies self and other, wanders far and unfettered.
Ziporyn 2009: If you are depending on some particular conditions,
Ziporyn 2009: even if you have the grace and ease of a Liezi,
Ziporyn 2009: you will still be unable to travel when there is no wind.
Ziporyn 2009: Such people can only wander far and unfettered after they attain that which they depend on—
Ziporyn 2009: and how much more so is this the case for Peng?
Ziporyn 2009: It is only one who can vanish into things and follow along with the great process of transformation
Ziporyn 2009: who can be truly free of dependence and thus constantly unobstructed?
Ziporyn 2009: She also complies with all dependent things,
Ziporyn 2009: allowing each to attain what it depends on.
Ziporyn 2009: Since they do not lose what they depend on,
Ziporyn 2009: So although I cannot make the dependent and the independent the same as each other,
Ziporyn 2009: the fact that each rests securely in its own character,
Ziporyn 2009: its Heavenly Mechanism unfolding of itself,
Ziporyn 2009: receiving it but not knowing how or why—
Ziporyn 2009: this is something I cannot make different among them.
Ziporyn 2009: And if even the independent is ultimately no different from the dependent,
Ziporyn 2009: how much less could there be any difference between the larger and smaller among the dependent?
Ziporyn 2009: is one who does not allow the external to harm the internal.
